courseTitle: The Effect of Ethylene on Fruit Ripening

pageData.titleName2: The Effect of Ethylene on Fruit Ripening

pageData.title: Overview
pageData.text: Plant growth needs to be regulated in order for plants to develop properly. Plant hormones, or <button class='glossary-text'>phytohormones</button>, have a prolonged effect on development and differentiation, even when present in small quantities, similar to hormones in our body. Ripening fruit produce the hormone <button class='glossary-text'>ethylene</button>, which is capable of diffusing through the air. In this lab, the effect of ethylene on unripe fruit will be examined.

pageData.subTitle: Overview video: The Effect of Ethylene on Fruit Ripening

text: Describe the roles that plant hormones play in plant physiology.
Examine the effect of <button class='glossary-text'>ethylene</button> on banana ripening.
Observe banana ripening and determine ways to delay this process.

pageData.text: Bananas are the most eaten fruit in United States<sup class='bodysubscript'>1</sup>. One reason for banana’s popularity is that they are inexpensive compared to other fruits. This is mainly because almost all bananas available in supermarkets are clones. New banana plants can easily be grown from cuttings of old plants meaning that they do not need to produce seeds or rely on pollinators to spread. The shape of bananas also helps them to be more easily and densely packed than other fruits. However, most bananas are grown in the Caribbean and South America which means that timing and transport are critical to make sure that they get to the store just at their peak ripeness without rotting on the journey. Bananas are usually transported in large climate-controlled containers, in some cases with the oxygen removed from the container, leaving the bananas in a nitrogen-only environment. This prevents any oxidation and keeps the bananas from beginning the ripening process.  The bananas are then stored in ripening chambers where controlled amounts of <button class='glossary-text'>ethylene</button> are pumped into the chamber to bring the bananas to the exact level of ripeness before they are transported to stores for sale.

1Stromberg, J. (2016, March 29). The improbable rise of the banana, America's most popular fruit. Vox.
https://www.vox.com/2016/3/29/11320900/banana-rise

pageData.desc: Ripe bananas on display at a grocery store.
pageData.altText: Ripe bananas on display at a grocery store.

pageData.text: Plants, like animals, develop different organ systems that are composed of distinct tissue types. The primary tissues are divided into three major types. <button class='glossary-text'>Dermal tissues</button> protect the plant from damage and prevent water loss. <button class='glossary-text'>Ground tissues</button> perform photosynthesis, store food, provide support, and allow for growth. <button class='glossary-text'>Vascular tissues</button> transport food and water to all parts of the plant (Figure 1). Differentiation into these various tissue types is partly controlled by hormones that exist naturally in plants. These plant hormones, or <button class='glossary-text'>phytohormones</button>, can be produced in response to environmental stimuli, such as light, gravity, and nutrients. Most hormones can be dissolved in water and are transported to the different plant cells via the vascular tissues. Since several hormones can be present at the same time, the concentration of each and their combination can elicit a wide variety of responses from the plant.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A cross-section of celery stalks showing several small dots of vascular bundles.
pageData.desc: Figure 1: A cross-section of celery stalks showing several small dots of vascular bundles.

pageData.text: One of the most well-studied groups of <button class='glossary-text'>phytohormones</button> is the <button class='glossary-text'>auxins</button>. These hormones play a role in growth, elongation of stems without increasing leaf formation, and maintaining flowers in a dormant state. Another group is the <button class='glossary-text'>gibberellins</button>. Members of this group stimulate stem growth by inducing cell division and elongation, along with stimulating the germination of dormant seeds. A third group, the <button class='glossary-text'>cytokinins</button>, increases root development and slows the aging of the leaves. Cytokinins frequently work in tandem with auxins to increase plant growth by stimulating cell division. This group can be found throughout the plant wherever cell division is taking place. <button class='glossary-text'>Abscisic acid</button>, another hormone, slows cell growth and initiates dormancy in plants. It is often found in plants that are experiencing a deficiency in nutrients. This compound controls water vapor loss through the leaf stoma.

<button class='glossary-text'>Ethylene</button> is unique among the plant hormones since it exists as a gas at room temperature. Therefore, the effects of ethylene are not restricted to one plant, but can instead travel through the air to affect surrounding plants as well. For example, when an herbivore, such as an antelope, eats the leaves of an acacia tree in Africa, the tree responds by producing ethylene. This ethylene then travels through the air to neighboring plants, which react to it by producing <button class='glossary-text'>leaf tannin</button>. This substance can be lethal to antelope and other animals that eat acacia leaves; thus, while now protecting the tree which was grazed upon, it will ensure the survival of the tree species.

pageData.question: Which of the following is NOT a phytohormone?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Phytohormones (plant hormones) include auxins, gibberellins, cytokinins, abscisic acid, and ethylene.

pageData.question: How are most hormones transported to the different plant cells?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Most hormones can be dissolved in water and are transported to the different plant cells via the vascular tissues.

A third group, the cytokinins, increases root development and slows the aging of the leaves. Cytokinins frequently work in tandem with auxins to increase plant growth by stimulating cell division. A third group, the cytokinins, increases root development and slows the aging of the leaves. Cytokinins frequently work in tandem with auxins to increase plant growth by stimulating cell division. pageData.text: Another function of <button class='glossary-text'>ethylene</button> is the stimulation of fruit ripening. When a fruit ripens, it produces ethylene, which will initiate the ripening process in surrounding fruits. Therefore, one spoiled fruit in a bowl will speed up ripening and potentially lead to spoiling of the surrounding fruits (“one bad apple spoils the whole barrel”). This effect can also lead to the premature ripening of fruits transported over long distances. Should one fruit in the cargo produce ethylene, the rest will start to ripen as well, thus reducing their storage time. To prevent this, shipping companies ventilate cargo spaces that transport fruit to extract the ethylene to ensure that fruit arrive fresh at their destination. Ventilation also prevents the buildup of carbon dioxide. As fruit begins to ripen, respiration increases. In an enclosed space, oxygen becomes depleted and carbon dioxide levels rise. In the absence of oxygen, yeast and other microbes begin to convert sugars in the fruit into ethanol. In some fruits, including bananas, an excess of ethanol causes alcohol dehydrogenases in the fruit to convert ethanol into ethylene, further speeding up the ripening process. In this lab, ethanol will be used to increase the availability of ethylene.

All of these hormones do not work independently but rather function in a delicate balance to maximize plant survival and procreation. Understanding plant hormones aids us in the production of food crops, increases the viability of fruits, and lengthens the storage time.

pageData.question: What is the purpose of ethanol in this investigation?

options.text: to neutralize the effects of ethylene

pageData.question: If one fruit in a shipping container produces ethylene, the rest will start to ripen as well. Which of the following strategies would prevent such premature ripening?

options.text: add more carbon dioxide to the container
package different types of fruits together

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, obtain bananas. Set up your bananas according to their treatment condition. For the uncovered control, place the bananas in an uncovered bowl. For the uncovered treated condition, place the bananas in a bowl with a medicine cup filled with ethanol. For the covered untreated condition, place the bananas in a sealed plastic bag. For the covered treated condition, place the bananas in a sealed plastic bag with a medicine cup filled with ethanol. Record your observations of each treatment condition each day for 8 days.

Wear your safety goggles and gloves at all times while conducting this investigation.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Procedure sections.
The bananas used in this experiment are not intended for human consumption.
Ethanol is flammable. Keep this chemical away from all flames and heat sources.
Ethanol is denatured and is very harmful if swallowed.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What are the main functions of the vascular tissues of a plant?

options.text: transport food and water to all parts of the plant
perform photosynthesis, store food, provide support, and allow for growth
protect the plant from damage and prevent water loss
cause growth and elongation of stems
slow cell growth and initiate dormancy

assestmentData.question: Match each phytohormone with its correct function.
Which of the following items do you need to supply yourself to complete the investigation?
Which of the following statements about ethylene is true?

options.text: Ethylene can travel through the air and affect surrounding plants.
Ethylene is transported via the water in plant vascular tissues.
Ethylene produced by a ripe fruit will inhibit ripening in surrounding fruits.
Ethylene is produced as a gas only in response to injury.
Ethylene is not considered a true phytohormone.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following safety hazards is associated with the ethanol provided in your kit for this investigation?

options.text: It will stain skin or clothing.
It is extremely harmful to aquatic life.

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the activity.
Obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.

In Activity 1, you will observe the effect of <button class='glossary-text'>ethylene</button> on banana ripening over 8 days by placing bananas in various environments. You will then record the number of green, ripe, and spoiled bananas in each treatment group.
Separate the bananas, making sure not to open the fruit and expose the soft interior. Should this happen, remove the banana from the activity since this will ruin the experiment.
Place 3 bananas in a bowl on a table, and mark these as Uncovered Control.
Place 3 bananas in a bowl. Place a small medicine cup filled with 10 mL of ethanol in the bowl, and mark this as Uncovered Treated.
Place 3 bananas in a clear plastic bag. Mark these as Covered Untreated.
Place 3 bananas and a small medicine cup filled with 10 mL of ethanol into a clear plastic bag. Mark this group as Covered Treated.
Optional: Place 3 bananas in a bowl. Add a small medicine cup filled with 10 mL of ethanol in the bowl. Position a fan so that it blows over these bananas only. Mark this group as Ventilated Treated.

Observe the ripening of each group of bananas and record the data in Data Table 1. Write a G for green, R for ripe, and S for spoiled bananas, along with the number of bananas that exhibit each characteristic after every letter.
Make sure the temperature stays at 15–25 °C.
Make sure that ethanol remains in the medicine cups, and add more (up to the 10-mL mark) if needed.
Record the number of green, ripe, and spoiled bananas in each group in Data Table 2.

text: Discard the ethanol in the sink while flushing with excess tap water.
Dispose of the bananas in household or yard waste.

data.title: Abscisic acid
data.content: A type of phytohormone that slows cell growth and initiates dormancy in a plant

data.title: Auxin
data.content: A type of phytohormone that play a role in growth, elongation, and maintaining flowers in a dormant state

data.title: Cytokinin
data.content: A type of phytohormone that increases root development and slows the aging of leaves

data.title: Dermal tissue
data.content: A major type of plant tissue that protects the plant from damage and prevents water loss

data.title: Ethylene
data.content: A gaseous phytohormone that initiates defense and ripening responses in a plant and neighboring plants

data.title: Gibberellins
data.content: A type of phytohormone that stimulates growth by inducing cell division and germination of dormant seeds

data.title: Ground tissue
data.content: A major type of plant tissue that performs photosynthesis, stores food, and provides support for growth

data.title: Leaf tannin
data.content: A plant substance that can be produced in response to injury

data.title: Vascular tissue
data.content: A major type of plant tissue that transports food and water to all parts of the plant
